title: b' Made in Detroit: A History of Art and Culture in the Motor City '
description:
b'



The embodiment of "Modern Times" was the assembly line and Detroit, dubbed "the capital of the Twentieth Century" played an important symbolic role in the modern imagination. Yet while  artists depicted Detroit's industry as an abstract emblem of twentieth century progress \xe2\x80\x94 and later of dystopian decline \xe2\x80\x94 the city has a complicated labor, racial, and political history that makes it and its art different from that of any other place. 

This seminar examines how Detroit has been presented in modern art, and the role that the arts and architecture have played in the city from the 1880's to the present. We will consider both works produced in Detroit that defined technology and urban culture for the world, and those that have particular local histories from the sleek factories that heralded modern architecture in America to the artificial past that Henry Ford assembled at Greenfield Village, from the heroic worker figures of Diego Rivera's murals to the controversies surrounding the Joe Louis monument and the Heidelberg Project, from \xe2\x80\x9cruin porn\xe2\x80\x9d and gentrification to prospects for the future. Students are encouraged to attend two day-long field trips which will include a visit to the exhibition \xe2\x80\x9cDiego Rivera and Frida Kahlo in Detroit\xe2\x80\x9d at the Detroit Institute of Arts. 


Required texts  (also on reserve) will include Terry Smith, Making the Modern; F. W. Taylor, Principles of Scientific Management; Karen Lucic, Charles Sheeler and the Cult of the Machine;
Thomas Sugrue, The Origins of the Urban Crisis; Walter Gropius, The New Architecture and the Bauhaus.


 HISTART category for concentration distributions: D. Europe and the United States, 4. Modern and Contemporary. Course Requirements:Informed participation in class discussion, brief response papers based on ambitious assigned readings and questions; a research paper prepared in stages throughout the semester.Intended Audience:some background in art history, design, American studies, history, or urban studies is recommended; a commitment to learning more about Detroit is essential.  

Permission of instructor required. Please email rzurier@umich.edu to learn more about the class.Class Format:Seminar'
advised_requisite: b'Upperclass standing; prior coursework in Art History, U.S. History, American Culture, or Urban studies, and permission of instructor.'

title: b' The American Revolution '
description:
b"An intensive course on the background to the Revolution, its 
progress, and the changes it wrought in American life. Emphasis on  America's mid-18th-century socioeconomic transformation, Britain's 
reorganization of her empire in the 1760s and 1770s, colonial  opposition, and the emergence of a uniquely American ideology.
Subsequent topics include the progress and dislocations of the 
military conflict, the attempt at confederation, and the culmination  of the Revolutionary movement in the iteration and early development  of the Constitution and Bill of Rights."

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description:
b'This is a course of many questions. Who \xe2\x80\x94 and what \xe2\x80\x94 is college for, in our diverse, unequal democracy?
How does college admissions really work? What are the rituals of "getting in"? How have people worked and fought for?educational opportunity in the US? How do students challenge and change the colleges they attend, through pressure, protest, and experiment?
Why have Americans invented so many different kinds of colleges? Who pays for higher education? Why do campuses look the way they do? How are today\xe2\x80\x99s students approaching the college-to-life transition? What kind of citizens do they become? What role will they play in national debates on higher education?
We will grapple with these questions through collaborative inquiry that builds advanced analytical, investigative, writing, speaking, and civic skills. These skills will emerge from vigorous reflection on pathways to educational opportunity, the exchange of research findings based on close encounters with scholarship and the archive, site visits to different kinds of colleges, guest presenters on entrepreneurship and \xe2\x80\x9cnontraditional\xe2\x80\x9d students, plus a \xe2\x80\x9cbicentennial special\xe2\x80\x9d project with U-M alumni.
There are six major themes in the course:
Educational Narratives and Self-Authoring: Your Story in Context
Getting In: How Pathways Work
Full Participation: Inclusion, Equity, and Diversity
Campus as Place: Reading the College Landscape
Higher Ed Change: Student Leadership and Public Debates
After College, What?: College, Career, CitizenshipCourse Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted'

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description:
b'What scenes and fantasies are conjured by the word \xe2\x80\x9cexotic"?  The Mystic East?  The Orient?  Pacific Beaches and Tiki Bars?  The writer Alden Jones explains, "Exoticism, the 'charm of the unfamiliar,' is a concept that might be applied to anything \xe2\x80\x94 a rainforest flower, a skyscraper, a person of any ethnicity \xe2\x80\x94 depending on who is beholding it and how unfamiliar it is to them."  In other words, \xe2\x80\x9cexotic\xe2\x80\x9d doesn\xe2\x80\x99t describe a quality or characteristic of  something, but rather, describes a way of seeing, a gaze. This course begins with this idea, and investigates what role exoticism has played in American literature, art, and music.
What is the relation between exoticism and American empire?
What have \xe2\x80\x9cexotic\xe2\x80\x9d things and places signified for Americans at various points in the nation\xe2\x80\x99s history?
Why and when do certain regions \xe2\x80\x94 like Asia, the Middle East, and the Pacific Islands \xe2\x80\x94 evoke exotic fantasies for Americans?
In investigating these questions, the course examines broader questions about race, ethnicity, sexuality, and difference as viewed through the lens of exoticism. Course readings will include novels, films, and other media.Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted'

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description: b'As its literature attests, Hawai\xe2\x80\x98i is simultaneously the uniquely multicultural fiftieth state of the Union, a colonial outpost, and the disputed sovereign nation of native Hawaiians.  As might be expected, the literature of Hawai\xe2\x80\x98i is a highly contested terrain ranging from works by native Hawaiian writers, \xe2\x80\x9clocal\xe2\x80\x9d writers, and works by \xe2\x80\x9cforeigners.\xe2\x80\x9d  This course allows students to read and study the literary and oral traditions of Hawai\xe2\x80\x98i, including works by writers of native Hawaiian, Chinese, Puerto Rican, Japanese, Filipino, and Korean descent, through competing paradigms which place Hawaii\xe2\x80\x99s literatures and cultures within the historical, social, and political contexts of western imperial expansion, globalization, Asian American literature, and the native Hawaiian movement toward autonomy and self-determination.  The literatures of Hawai\xe2\x80\x98i have been and can be read through these frameworks as well as how they also problematize and contest these categories.  We will examine dominant representations of the islands by Melville, London and Twain as well as contestatory representations by \xe2\x80\x9clocal\xe2\x80\x9d writers such as Balaz, Holt, Trask, Murayama, Pak, Yamanaka, Zamora Linmark and Cobb Keller.  The course will also contextualize these authors within the broader critical paradigms of mainland Asian American literature as well as Pacific Island literatures.Course Requirements:Midterm paper, Final research paper, presentationsIntended Audience:Upperclass standingClass Format:Seminar'

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description: b'Tourism is both a mode of travel and a highly profitable industry that markets places, experiences, and cultures as commodities to be consumed. In this course, we will look at how tourism developed in the United States through the eyes of tourists and through the ways sites are packaged and sold as destinations. By exploring both historical and contemporary dimensions of tourism \xe2\x80\x94  including the marketing of the Southwest and the emergence of touring infrastructure in the form of hotels, motels, and national parks \xe2\x80\x94 this course will focus on the ways in which tourism has been inextricably (and often problematically) linked to leisure, gender and racial identity, and preservation. Likewise, we will ask how tourism shapes spaces, locales, and the individuals who live and work in them.Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted'

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description: b'How did an entire century\xe2\x80\x94the twentieth century\xe2\x80\x94supposedly belong to one nation-state, the United States of America? In this course we will explore how and why the United States became the leading military, economic, and diplomatic power in the world. We will trace the geo-political ascendance of the United States and its consequences on the lives and experiences of people both domestically and abroad. We will take a more global approach to the history of U.S. foreign relations, exploring\xe2\x80\x94from the end of the nineteenth century to the current moment\xe2\x80\x94not only how the United States affected the world, but also how the world affected the United States. Moreover, we will consider America in the long twentieth century not only as a geo-political entity, but also as a historical place from which to examine global histories of power, violence, and difference. Finally, this course will interrogate the legacies of the \xe2\x80\x9cAmerican Century\xe2\x80\x9d in the new millennium.Course Requirements:Reading and Writing.Intended Audience:Juniors and SeniorsClass Format:Seminar'

title: b' American Immigration: Sociological Perspectives '
description: b'Both the study of immigration and the questions that study raises are at the very root of social science. In this course we survey the literature that gives evidence of the major concepts, questions, and approaches which sociologists have used to study immigration, as well as the interface between immigration, race, and ethnicity in America. In this seminar, we will seek to focus each session on a different topic, such as the origin of ethnic stratification, race, and racism; the contrasting theoretical explanations of assimilation and internal colonialism for the reality of group differences in social outcomes in America; the different levels of analysis, micro vs. macro approaches to immigration; the causes and consequences of the differential incorporation of immigrants in American society; political vs. economic immigrants as different social types; middleman minorities vs. the ethnic enclave vs. the ethnic economy as models of immigrant adaptation; women and migration; and social networks and gender as the link between micro and macro levels of analysis.Course Requirements:The goal of this seminar is for each student to work on a paper on a topic of his or her own choosing that relates to immigration, race, and ethnicity. If done well, such a paper could be used as the basis for a dissertation prospectus. The research paper might also be further developed into a publishable paper while in graduate school. If polished enough, it could be used to send away for external funds from a foundation. \r\nAs a seminar, the informed participation of class members is essential, and will be taken into account for the final grade. Each student will be responsible for providing written comments for the two first drafts to one other student in class, as well as for his or her own final research prospectus. Each student will also be responsible for presenting three or four of the readings in the syllabus to the class, bringing in a handout summarizing the work for everyone in the class.'
advised_requisite: b'Graduate standing; seniors with permission of instructor.'

title: b' Topics in American Studies '
description:
b'This course provides an introduction to the literature of American history, with an emphasis on chronological breadth, thematic diversity, important foundational texts, and key methodological and theoretical innovations in recent scholarship. The course is not designed to cover every important debate in U.S. historiography, nor is it possible to present a comprehensive portrait of five centuries of history on the North American continent. Rather, it is organized around a series of critical historical episodes and historiographical debates, with each session devoted to a major book and accompanying articles or a pair of books (usually excerpted). Goals of the course include;

the development of critical analytical skills in the assessment of historiographical and methodological trends, especially beyond your particular chronological specialization and subfield(s) of interest,
the acquirement of a basic familiarity and fluency in discussing historical themes and scholarly debates that have shaped this profession,
an introduction to key texts that should be a staple of reading lists for preliminary exams, especially since the department requires one of your fields to span the chronological divide between early and late U.S. history, and
a collective experience that fosters intellectual community among members of the entering Americanist cohort of 2015.Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:AMCULT 601.001/HISTORY 611 is a core requirement for all first-year graduate students in American history, and the seminar is open to students in Anthro/History, American Culture and other related fields.Class Format:No data submitted'

title: b' Topics in American Studies '
description: b'Anthropologist Sherry Ortner once observed per Marshall Sahlins\xe2\x80\x99s aphorism, \xe2\x80\x9cWhatever Happened to \xe2\x80\x98Late Capitalism\xe2\x80\x99?/It became neo-liberalism,\xe2\x80\x9d that around the year 2000 academic conversations effectively substituted \xe2\x80\x9cneoliberalism\xe2\x80\x9d for \xe2\x80\x9clate capitalism.\xe2\x80\x9d Ortner\xe2\x80\x99s observation implies that \xe2\x80\x9cpostmodernism\xe2\x80\x9d as an object of theoretical inquiry also was subsumed under the moniker of the neoliberal. As critics have experimented with engaging \xe2\x80\x9cpost-Fordist affect,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cpost-postmodernism,\xe2\x80\x9d et cetera, most have had to concede pace Michel Foucault that the implementation of neoliberal doctrine depends upon the hybridization of the aesthetic and the economic. In this seminar, we will address site-specific and time-sensitive aesthetic-economic joins by considering the other millennial pairing of the global and the neoliberal. Just as critics once pluralized modernities, we generally will think the global as an umbrella category, while also engaging particularly neoliberal doctrines in the context of the Americas. Intended to function as an introduction to two keywords often cited generically in trans/disciplinary conversations, no prior theoretical experience or engagement with the \xe2\x80\x9cneoliberal\xe2\x80\x9d and the \xe2\x80\x9cglobal\xe2\x80\x9d is necessary for seminar participants. Key texts in our discussions in all likelihood will include Foucault\xe2\x80\x99s The Birth of Biopolitics, Lauren Berlant\xe2\x80\x99s Cruel Optimism, Claudia Rankine\xe2\x80\x99s Citizen, Paul Chan\xe2\x80\x99s Waiting for Godot in New Orleans, Jo\xc3\xa3o Biehl\xe2\x80\x99s Vita: Life in a Zone of Social Abandonment, Alejandro Gonz\xc3\xa1lez I\xc3\xb1\xc3\xa1rritu\xe2\x80\x99s Biutiful, and Mohamedou Ould Slahi\xe2\x80\x99s Guant\xc3\xa1namo Diary.'

title: b' Topics in American Studies '
description: b'This discussion-based seminar course explores the field of \xe2\x80\x9canimal theory\xe2\x80\x9d as a strain of the contemporary posthumanities that seeks to rearticulate the Cartesian human-animal species divide fundamental to modern Western philosophical and literary thought.  While the main focus of the course is current critical work that lies at the intersection of biopolitics and postmodernity, we begin by tracing field development from Ovid\xe2\x80\x99s Metamorphoses to the medieval and Renaissance periods through the literary and medical figure of the original monster, the human-animal hybrid. The wide-ranging impact and intersectional nature of animal studies is such that it will afford us a relatively comprehensive understanding of current scholarly thought in the posthumanities, particularly at its frontiers of queer studies, biopolitics, affect studies, human and animal \xe2\x80\x9crights\xe2\x80\x9d discourses, neuroscience, and environmentalism.\nReadings in the first, foundational half of the course include work by Descartes, Spinoza, and Par\xc3\xa9, as well as the excerpted beginnings of contemporary animal theory by Levinas, Derrida, Bataille, Foucault, Heidegger, and Deleuze and Guattari. The second half of the course is devoted to the contemporary theoretical work of Haraway, Agamben, Wolfe, Latour, and Chen, as well as creative literary work by Coetzee, Angela Carter, and others. Course Requirements:Course requirements include in-class reports and an extensive final research paper that may be written as an article for journal submission.'

title: b' Topics in American Studies '
description:
b'Students practice performance as a way of reconstructing theatre history. The class will focus on the repertory of the nineteenth-century African American actor Ira Aldridge. During the first half of the academic term, the class researches historical gestures at the University of Michigan Museum then performs them with text in the Duderstadt Video Studio. During the second half of the semester, the class researches the life and history of Ira Aldridge and performs scenes from his repertory with appropriate period gestures. Students write a research paper about some aspect of Aldridge\xe2\x80\x99s career and then publish their research on a public website.
 Students Learn:

How to reconstruct historical performance
How to physicalize 19th-century gestures and perform them with text
About the biography, repertory and historical context of actor Ira Aldridge
How to research and write a research paper about 19thcentury performance.
How to upload historical images and data into a computer tool.


Required Readings:


Practical Illustrations of Rhetorical Gestures and Action by Henry Siddons
 Red Velvet by Lolita Chakrabarti
 The Black Doctor by Ira Aldridge
 The Padlock by Charles Dibdin
 Othello by William Shakespeare


Online and published resources about Ira Aldridge including but not limited to:


Marshall, Herbert and Mildred Stock. Ira Aldridge: The Negro Tragedian, (Washington DC: Howard University Press, 1993).
  
Kujawinska Courtney and Maria Lukowska. Ira Aldridge 1807-1967, (Frankfurt: Peter Lang, 2009).
  
Lindfors, Bernth, Editor. Ira Aldridge: The African Roscius. Rochester: University of Rochester Press, 2007).
  
Shalom, Jack, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Ira Aldridge Troupe: Early Black Minstrelsy in Philadelphia,\xe2\x80\x9d African American Review, Volume 26, Number 4 (1994).
 
Dewberry, Jonathan, \xe2\x80\x9cThe African Grove Theatre and Company,\xe2\x80\x9d Black American Literature Forum, Volume 16, (1982).
 Intended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:This course is an interdisciplinary course in which students work as a team from within their discipline (history, performance, cultural studies) to excavate an applied history of African American performance.'

title: b' Interdisciplinary Approaches to Latina/o Studies '
description: b'Latino Studies is an interdisciplinary approach to the study of Puerto Rican, Mexican, Cuban, Caribbean, Central American, and Latin American communities in the US. Latina/o Studies that offers a rubric for understanding not only the interconnections between diverse Latina/o communities but also the differences that sometimes divide them. This course will expose students to core knowledge about Latina/o histories and communities as well as the various disciplinary rubrics through which Latina/o Studies is elaborated including literary and historical studies, studies of immigration and citizenship, religious studies, and media studies. As a true interdisciplinary \xe2\x80\x9cintroduction\xe2\x80\x9d to the study of Latina/os in the U.S., the pedagogical aim of this course is to help graduate students develop the background knowledge, theoretical language and methodological skills needed to analyze the histories, cultural production, and material realities of Latina/os in the U.S.'

title: b' Knowledge/Power/Practice in Science, Technology, and Medicine '
description: b'This graduate readings seminar is designed to provide a comprehensive introduction to some of the major themes and issues that occupy the field of Science and Technology Studies.  Drawing on scholarship in history, sociology, philosophy, anthropology, and information studies, we will mix theoretical material with more empirically oriented studies.  The course will focus particularly on the relation between social, political, and cultural contexts and the development of ideas, practices, tools, and objects within science, technology, and medicine.Intended Audience:No particular expertise in a scientific field is expected or required of participants.'

title: b' Studies in American Cultural History '
description: b'This course explores classic texts and current methodological problems in U.S. cultural history, broadly defined. The reading list is deliberately expansive in scope, cutting across multiple hemispheres, much of the past three centuries, and competing approaches from U.S. cultural history, American studies, and British cultural studies. In so doing, it takes a capacious approach to \xe2\x80\x9cculture\xe2\x80\x9d itself. In some cases, we\xe2\x80\x99ll focus on culture in the aesthetic senses: high and low, visual and textual, vernacular and commercial. But at other moments, we\xe2\x80\x99ll look at culture in the broader anthropological modes of customs, traditions, and values. Above all, we\xe2\x80\x99ll explore \xe2\x80\x9cthe cultural\xe2\x80\x9d as an evolving set of methodological approaches now being applied to sources and subjects previously understood as the provinces of other subfields. One of our central questions, in fact, will involve the long-term effects and future directions of the \xe2\x80\x9ccultural turn,\xe2\x80\x9d a phenomenon now described as the most important disciplinary development of the late 20th century. Simply put: what is cultural history now? How has it changed in recent decades, and where is it moving in the current conjuncture? One final note: in early April, I will be running a national conference at UM entitled "A New Materialism? Rethinking Global Capitalism at the Nexus of Culture and Political Economy." This event will include a number of U.S. cultural historians from around the country: Kathleen Brown, Andrew Zimmerman, Seth Rockman, Alison Isenberg, Nan Enstad, Elspeth Brown, Nathan Connolly, and possibly 1-2 others. The plan is to include recent work by many of these scholars as part of the reading list for History 686. I will also ask students to attend the two-day conference (April 1-2), meet the authors, and discuss their pre-circulated papers, which will be available in early March. Please see Wolverine Access in December for a finalized book list.Course Requirements:Regular attendance and active participation; short response papers for most of the weekly assignments (with ~3-4 weeks off over the course of the term); a ~10 pp. \xe2\x80\x9cagenda\xe2\x80\x9d essay on the future of cultural history at the end of the term.Intended Audience:Ph.D. students in History and related humanities disciplines. Students outside of the History Department should contact the instructor for approval before enrolling.Class Format:3 hour seminar.'

title: b' Methodologies in American Culture '
description: b'This class is designed to assist first-year (graduate) students in making the transition from histories and theories of American studies to individual research \xe2\x80\x94 i.e., your own work. The larger goal is a substantial research paper based on primary sources that is to be completed by the end of the first year. Students are not expected to have a fixed or finished sense of their long-term research plans at that point, and each student will define the program of research in his/her own way. Above all, AMCULT 698 seeks to help each student begin the process of finding an independent voice as an interdisciplinary scholar and academic writer. This course will include staggered deadlines throughout the semester for revised prospectuses, bibliographies, and rough drafts, as well as some form of peer review.'

title: b' Advanced Graduate Seminar in Primary Research '
description: b"Should be taken as early as possible in the student's dissertation work. Student's may enroll in it at any point after advancement to candidacy, although it will ordinarily be taken immediately after the field examinations have been completed. This course will be designed to support students in getting their dissertations under way. However, some students may frame a dissertation topic early and wish to begin working on it before taking the field examinations; therefore, the course will ensure that it is also useful to students who are further along with their work. The class will include basic questions about research methods, collective critique of work in draft, discussion of ethics of scholarship and academic life, practical information about submitting papers for conferences and articles for publication, and visits from Program faculty from a variety of fields to discuss professional issues."

title: b' Special Research '
description:
b"It is expected that each student will do substantial work in more than one discipline and that the course of study will
 delineate appropriate research skills to be acquired and theoretical concerns to be explored  An American Culture graduate student will be required to complete an
 introductory research seminar in the student's field of interest. The option of satisfying this requirement in American Culture
 699 or 899 is available for those students who do not have another appropriate seminar that fits their interests."

title: b' Dissertation/Precandidate '
description: b'Election for dissertation work by doctoral student not yet admitted as a Candidate.'
advised_requisite: b'Graduate standing. Election for dissertation work by doctoral student not yet admitted as a Candidate.'

title: b' Graduate Student Instructor Training Program '
description: b'A seminar for all beginning graduate student instructors, consisting of a two day orientation before the term starts and periodic workshops/meetings during the Fall Term. Beginning graduate student instructors are required to register for this class.'

title: b' Dissertation/Candidate '
description: b'Graduate School authorization for admission as a doctoral Candidate. N.B. The defense of the dissertation (the final oral examination) must be held under a full term Candidacy enrollment period.'

title: b' Rednecks, Queers, and Country Music '
description: b'What does country music or the \xe2\x80\x9credneck\xe2\x80\x9d have to do with the queer? In America\xe2\x80\x99s dominant middle-class culture country is linked to heterosexual white, rural, working-class, southern, and Midwestern people and is often invoked as a symbol of \xe2\x80\x9credneck\xe2\x80\x9d bigotry. Queer identity, on the other hand, is associated with gay men and multicultural urban, bourgeois, coastal lifestyles. The intersection of these seemingly incompatible categories calls into question prevalent notions concerning each of them. Thus this seminar asks how music that to many people sounds homophobic and racist serves as a medium for multicultural social and erotic exchange among queer country fans.Course Requirements:Assignments include country music listening; readings, films, and media reports on country music studies, social science and humanities literature on rural and southern LGBT life, and social theory on socioeconomic class; written critical responses to course materials; and a final PowerPoint presentation to the class.Intended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:Seminar'
advised_requisite: b"One course in Women's Studies or American Culture."

title: b' Latin American & Latino/a Film Studies '
description:
b'Este curso plantea explorar las distintas formas de desplazamiento que se representan en la cinematograf\xc3\xada contempor\xc3\xa1nea de/y sobre Am\xc3\xa9rica Latina, ya sea \xc3\xa9ste generado por el exilio, la dislocaci\xc3\xb3n geogr\xc3\xa1fica, temporal, o personal, o bien por el surgumiento de movimientos sociales como revoluciones o guerrillas. Discutiremos c\xc3\xb3mo se articula el desplazamiento y sus modalidades en pa\xc3\xadses claves latinoamericanos cuya historia reciente ha quedado marcada por el desplazamiento de sus habitantes.

Siguiendo un formato de cine-f\xc3\xb3rum, los estudiantes participar\xc3\xa1n en discusi\xc3\xb3n de escenas y actividades en grupo dise\xc3\xb1adas para explorar a fondo las pel\xc3\xadculasseleccionadas de estos tres pa\xc3\xadses.  Asimismo, escribir\xc3\xa1n tres rese\xc3\xb1as cinematogr\xc3\xa1ficas para cada uno de los bloques geogr\xc3\xa1ficos del curso y un proyecto final, adem\xc3\xa1s de ofrecer.


This course counts as elective credit for the Spanish academic minor.Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted'

title: b' Latin American & Latino/a Film Studies '
description:
b"This course is a survey of the work of women filmmakers in Latin America, from the earliest years of cinema to the present. These women filmmakers have been left out of most established histories of Latin American cinema. This course will consider the films of diverse women filmmakers in relation to national film movements, transnational  feminist projects, and international art cinema circuits in order to articulate their position within Latin American cinema history. 

The course is loosely organized around film mode. The first part of the course considers fiction filmmaking in Latin American cinema, from the work of women film pioneers who contributed to the development of the early cinema and the New Latin American Cinema to more contemporary women authors. Alongside these feature-length fiction films, we will study the evolution of feminist film criticism in Anglo-European Film Studies as a project that reinvented the cinema in relationship to women\xe2\x80\x99s subjectivity and women\xe2\x80\x99s points of view, in order to adopt and adapt its methods in discussing women\xe2\x80\x99s filmmaking from Latin America. For this first part of the course, students will produce a short video essay incorporating the lessons of feminist film theory in the close analysis of a media text. 

The second part of the course will turn to non-fiction filmmaking in the region, in order to explore the politics of feminist documentary and its role in  women\xe2\x80\x99s movements and women\xe2\x80\x99s rights struggles. The course will tease out the distinctions between feminisms considered historically over time and unevenly across space. Students will be responsible for a final paper on a women's rights issue that intersects with the use of non-fiction filmmaking or media activism in Latin America.



This course counts as elective credit toward the Spanish minor.Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted"

title: b' Made in Detroit: A History of Art and Culture in the Motor City '
description:
b'



The embodiment of "Modern Times" was the assembly line and Detroit, dubbed "the capital of the Twentieth Century" played an important symbolic role in the modern imagination. Yet while  artists depicted Detroit's industry as an abstract emblem of twentieth century progress\xe2\x80\x94and later of dystopian decline\xe2\x80\x94the city has a complicated labor, racial, and political history that makes it and its art different from that of any other place. This seminar examines how Detroit has been presented in modern art, and the role that the arts and architecture have played in the city from the 1880's to the present. We will consider both works produced in Detroit that defined technology and urban culture for the world and those that have particular local histories, from the sleek factories that heralded modern architecture in America to the artificial past that Henry Ford assembled at Greenfield Village, from the heroic worker figures of Diego Rivera's murals to the controversies surrounding the Joe Louis monument and the Heidelberg Project, from \xe2\x80\x9cruin porn\xe2\x80\x9d and gentrification to prospects for the future. 

HISTART Category for Concentration Distributions:  D. Europe and the US, 4. Modern and Contemporary. 


Permission of instructor required. Please email rzurier@umich.edu to learn more about the class.

Required texts  (also on reserve) will include Terry Smith, Making the Modern; F. W. Taylor, Principles of Scientific Management; Karen Lucic, Charles Sheeler and the Cult of the Machine;
Thomas Sugrue, The Origins of the Urban Crisis; Walter Gropius, The New Architecture and the Bauhaus.Course Requirements:Informed participation in class discussion (25%), brief response papers based on ambitious assigned readings and questions (25%); a research paper prepared in stages throughout the semester. (50%) Students are required to attend two day-long field trips which will include a visit to the Detroit Institute of Arts. Intended Audience:upperclassmen interested in modern cities or modern art, willing to take on challenging readings.Class Format:Seminar'
advised_requisite: b'Upperclass standing; prior coursework in Art History, U.S. History, American Culture, or Urban studies, and permission of instructor.'

title: b' The American Revolution '
description:
b"An intensive course on the background to the Revolution, its 
progress, and the changes it wrought in American life. Emphasis on  America's mid-18th-century socioeconomic transformation, Britain's 
reorganization of her empire in the 1760s and 1770s, colonial  opposition, and the emergence of a uniquely American ideology.
Subsequent topics include the progress and dislocations of the 
military conflict, the attempt at confederation, and the culmination  of the Revolutionary movement in the iteration and early development  of the Constitution and Bill of Rights.Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted"

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description:
b'
 How has the debate on U.S. national security during the War on Terror been framed?
 How might our perceptions of Arabs and Islam limit international security and cooperation?
 What impact do U.S.-Middle East relations have on Arab and Muslim American communities? 

\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x9cWhy Do They Hate Us?: Perspectives on 9/11\xe2\x80\x9d explores key debates in the War on Terror, including over the causes of terrorism, the clash of civilizations thesis, civil liberties vs. national security, torture, and racial profiling. The course seeks a comprehensive view of how scholars, politicians, and citizens have understood and experienced 9/11 and its aftermath. We will explore materials such as scholarly writings, media representations, cultural and artistic work, government policies and laws. This course takes an interdisciplinary approach that brings together readings from cultural studies, media studies, political science, postcolonial studies, U.S. race and ethnic studies, and gender studies, revealing the interplay between debates at home and policies abroad."Course Requirements:A weekly blog post and two position papers. Students are required to meet with the professor about their writing and revise and resubmit one position paper.Intended Audience:It is strongly recommended, but not required to have taken at least one course in American Culture, Women\xe2\x80\x99s Studies, or Middle East Studies.Class Format:No data submitted'

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description: b'When in 1775 thirteen North American colonies moved to overthrow British rule, they delivered a major blow to European empire in the New World. Later, President James Monroe\xe2\x80\x99s 1823 challenge to Europeans monarchs if they attempted further expansion in the Americas seemed to confirm that the US was fundamentally anti-imperialist. Yet, this stance had been earlier contradicted in 1819 when Monroe obtained congressional funding to fund the privately owned American colony of Liberia, West Africa, the capital of which (Monrovia) was named in his honor.\nSome twenty-five years later the United States fought an expansionist war with Mexico (1846-1848), which yielded territories that later became Arizona, California, Colorado, New Mexico, Nevada, Texas, and Utah. In 1898 the United States annexed what had been the sovereign nation of Hawaii, while at the same time fighting a so-called anti-imperial war on Spain in support of Cuban and Filipino independence movements. But by the end of that year the United States took militarily control of Cuba, Puerto Rico, and the Philippines, which then set the nation at odds with island revolutionaries.\nOver one hundred years later, and long after the demise of old European empires, the United States is on the one hand vilified as the reincarnation of Imperial Rome, while also expected on the other hand to intervene in anti-totalitarian revolutions in North Africa and the Middle East. While the U.S. does not have formal colonies, American overseas \xe2\x80\x9cpossessions\xe2\x80\x9d do exist, e.g., Guantanamo Bay, Puerto Rico, Guam, the U.S. Virgin Islands, etc. Is \xe2\x80\x9cAmerican Imperialism\xe2\x80\x9d therefore, a misnomer?Students are asked to draw their own conclusions by analyzing a variety of historical and cultural materials (including visual culture, photography, filmmaking, fiction, poetry, political speeches, popular journalism, etc.) that continue to shape, condition, and express how Americans see themselves with respect to the rest of the world.Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted'

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description: b'New media are far from new. The World Wide Web is now more than twenty years old, digital games can be found on every platform, and social media\xe2\x80\x99s visual, textual, and cultural practices govern many aspects of users\xe2\x80\x99 experiences of their own lived environments. This course will trace the suppressed history of queer inventors, programmers, and developers in digital technology and games, analyze key texts in queer media theory, and pay particular attention to changing notions of the body, race, and gender in social media and games.Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted'

title: b' Capstone Seminar in American Culture '
description:
b'The intersection of race, genius and nationality has been for Americans of African descent a story of struggle, disillusion, rejection and great accomplishment. The lives and work of the four African Americans represent genius both in their fields, in their country and in the world. Their genius is their ability to transform and profoundly change the paradigms of their fields of endeavor. W.E.B. Dubois for his work on race theory which continues to be the foundational work of all academic and intellectual projects on critical race theory. Ida B. Wells Barnett radically changed the entire view of Black masculinity in America by her relentless attack on lynching. Her work still resonates today where Black manhood is still under siege. Muhammad Ali represents in the world what greatness means. He was not only a great athlete but his genius was that he changed the paradigm of what an athlete should be. He was a fierce race man, speaking fearlessly against the injustices suffered by his people while occupying a space of reverence in the world for him and his boxing accomplishments. Michael Jackson has shifted the paradigm of popular music in America and in the world. Popular music is no longer about singing, it is about performing, dancing and style. It is now both aural and visual. This is the legacy of Michael Jackson who is an American genius, his art being a syncretism of the powerful African and African American traditions of music and performance as well as the musical masters of American theatre and film. 

The objectives of this class are: 


To familiarize the students with the work and accomplishment of these four persons 
To examine these lives and evaluate whether their genius is understood and whether their contributions are given their proper place as Americans or are they celebrated only in African American communities. 
Critically examine genius and how race impacts this in the U.S. and in the world 
Through writing projects produce pieces that might be considered publishable either in blogs or other media. 

The texts and readings in the class as well as visual material will be used as the foundation to build ideas for writing. Course Requirements:No data submittedIntended Audience:No data submittedClass Format:No data submitted'
